channel.title: Picture in java!
channel.description: How can i make a picture appear in a JFrame?

item.title: Picture in java!
item.dc:creator: @Nader_H.I.M Nader[H.I.M]
item.description:
@Nader_H.I.M wrote:

[quote=“la­wl, post:8, topic:289481”][quote author=Speljohan link=topic=382657.msg2874143#msg2874143 date=1247951902]
Problem here is that Image does not have a constructor that takes arguments.
[/quote]
i thought that at first but wasnt sure
ImageIcon can just take a string to the file path[/quote]
Correct, i just wrote a general example but it could be something like:

ImageIcon icon = new ImageIcon("path to image");

Read full topic

item.title: Picture in java!
item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:
@qauters wrote:

class JPictureBox extends JFrame
{
    ImageIcon ii = null;

    public JPictureBox(String image)
    {
         ii = new ImageIcon(image);
    }

    public void paint(Graphics g)
    {
         if(ii != null)
             ii.paintIcon(this, g, 0, 0);
    }
};

Something like that, easy to implement.

Edit:
I see Unhandled suggested it while I was typing

Read full topic

item.title: Picture in java!
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

IMHO, the cleanest way would be to create a PictureBox control (surprised Swing doesn’t have one already) that uses Frell’s method to display the image. You could inherit from JPanel and override the paint method.

Read full topic

using a label to display an image is sometimes a lot better than other methods, and usually cleaner

item.title: Picture in java!
item.dc:creator: @chrisn2323 chrisn2323
item.description:
@chrisn2323 wrote:

[quote=“Unhandled, post:4, topic:289481”][quote author=Nader[H.I.M] link=topic=382657.msg2873740#msg2873740 date=1247930307]
You can Declare some Jlabel component with an ImageIcon , example:

ImageIcon i = new ImageIcon(new Image("image's path"));
JLabel j = new JLabel(i);

then you can just set its size to that of the Jframe:

 j.setSize(this.getSize());

finally add it to the Jframe:

 this.add(j);

[/quote]
That is an utterly retarded way to accomplish this.[/quote]
looooooooooooooooooooooooool

im sry but this made me laugh really hard

Read full topic

item.title: Picture in java!
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

[quote=“Nader[H.I.M”]link=topic=382657.msg2873740#msg2873740 date=1247930307]
You can Declare some Jlabel component with an ImageIcon , example:

ImageIcon i = new ImageIcon(new Image("image's path"));
JLabel j = new JLabel(i);

then you can just set its size to that of the Jframe:

 j.setSize(this.getSize());

finally add it to the Jframe:

 this.add(j);

That is an utterly retarded way to accomplish this.

Read full topic

item.description:
@Nader_H.I.M wrote:

You can Declare some Jlabel component with an ImageIcon , example:

ImageIcon i = new ImageIcon(new Image("image's path"));
JLabel j = new JLabel(i);

then you can just set its size to that of the Jframe:

 j.setSize(this.getSize());

finally add it to the Jframe:

 this.add(j);
